title: I\_T\_I Ligature
content:
I wanted to create an ITI ligature and was curious…

How often would various combinations of accented I characters end up in that sequence, if at all?

i.e.

Iacute\_T\_Iacute ligature

or

Iacute\_T\_Idieresis ligature

I'd like to keep it simple but accommodate the possible combinations, I'm not familiar with how accented characters are used, if ever, in sequence. (whether mixed or consistent)

Thanks,

Mike
author: Mike Jarboe

comments.content: In Old Norse and Icelandic quite often, the adjective _lítill -- lítinn_, its feminine forms _lítil -- lítin_ and plural _lítillar_ (meaning little or small) is an everyday-word that is also used in a whole bunch of compound-words, and then there's the adverb _lítit_. There are other words with this combination, but this is probably the most frequently used.

Latin: MĪTIS (soft [nominative]), MĪTĪ (soft [dative])

Yoruba: TÍTÍ (until), TÍTÌ (street)

Māori: TĪTĪMAKO, or how about TĪTITI
